title: Mace Neufeld
text:
Mace Alvin Neufeld (July 13, 1928 – January 21, 2022) was an American film and television producer.
Life and career.
Neufeld was born July 13, 1928, in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a>, the son of Margaret Ruth (<a href="married%20and%20maiden%20names">née</a> Braun) and Philip M. Neufeld, a stockbroker. He graduated from <a href="Yale%20University">Yale University</a>. He married Helen Katz in 1954, and has three children, Bradley, Glenn and Nancy.
In the 1950s, Neufeld became a <a href="talent%20agent">talent agent</a> and managed <a href="Don%20Knotts">Don Knotts</a>, <a href="Don%20Adams">Don Adams</a>, <a href="Randy%20Newman">Randy Newman</a>, <a href="Neil%20Diamond">Neil Diamond</a>, <a href="Jim%20Croce">Jim Croce</a> and <a href="Jay%20Ward">Jay Ward</a>. Neufeld entered television series production in the late 1970s. His productions of the time included the variety show "<a href="The%20Captain%20and%20Tennille">The Captain and Tennille</a>", which ran from 1976 to 1977 on <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>, "<a href="The%20Kids%20from%20C.A.P.E.R.">The Kids from C.A.P.E.R.</a>", which ran from 1976 through 1977 on <a href="CBS">CBS</a>, and "<a href="Quark%20%28TV%20series%29">Quark</a>", which ran for one year in 1978 on <a href="NBC">NBC</a>. He also became a film producer, beginning with "<a href="The%20Omen">The Omen</a>" in 1976, along with its sequels. Neufeld next produced the <a href="TV-movie">TV-movie</a> "<a href="Angel%20on%20My%20Shoulder%20%28film%29">Angel on My Shoulder</a>" on ABC 1980, as well as the features "<a href="The%20Frisco%20Kid">The Frisco Kid</a>" (the first of several film projects with <a href="Harrison%20Ford">Harrison Ford</a>) in 1979, "<a href="The%20Funhouse">The Funhouse</a>" in 1981, and "<a href="Transylvania%206-5000%20%281985%20film%29">Transylvania 6-5000</a>" in 1985. Neufeld's small screen work continued, including a 1981 family drama "<a href="American%20Dream%20%28TV%20series%29">American Dream</a>" and the fantasy of "<a href="The%20Magic%20Planet">The Magic Planet</a>" (both on ABC), as well as "" on NBC and the adventure of "<a href="Lightning%20Force">Lightning Force</a>", a syndicated series, from 1991 to 1992.
His production company, with mogul <a href="Marvin%20Davis">Marvin Davis</a>, was followed by one set up with <a href="Robert%20Rehme">Robert G. Rehme</a>, which arranged an exclusive production deal with <a href="Paramount%20Pictures">Paramount</a>. Launching their partnership in the early 1990s, the team went on to shepherd "<a href="Patriot%20Games%20%28film%29">Patriot Games</a>" and "<a href="Clear%20and%20Present%20Danger%20%28film%29">Clear and Present Danger</a>", based on the bestselling books of <a href="Tom%20Clancy">Tom Clancy</a>. They also produced 1991's "<a href="Flight%20of%20the%20Intruder">Flight of the Intruder</a>". Neufeld had earlier produced Clancy's "<a href="The%20Hunt%20for%20Red%20October%20%28film%29">The Hunt for Red October</a>" with <a href="Jerry%20Sherlock">Jerry Sherlock</a>. When Rehme exited the partnership to become President of the <a href="Academy%20of%20Motion%20Picture%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences</a>, Neufeld went on to produce yet another Tom Clancy adaptation starring Ben Affleck, "<a href="The%20Sum%20of%20All%20Fears%20%28film%29">The Sum of All Fears</a>", as well as "<a href="Bless%20the%20Child">Bless the Child</a>", "<a href="Lost%20in%20Space%20%28film%29">Lost in Space</a>" and "<a href="Asylum%20%282005%20film%29">Asylum</a>".
Neufeld was a producer on "<a href="Sahara%20%282005%20film%29">Sahara</a>", released in 2005, and on "<a href="Invictus%20%28film%29">Invictus</a>", directed by <a href="Clint%20Eastwood">Clint Eastwood</a>, starring <a href="Morgan%20Freeman">Morgan Freeman</a> and <a href="Matt%20Damon">Matt Damon</a>. Neufeld produced "", starring <a href="Chris%20Pine">Chris Pine</a>, and "<a href="Tom%20Clancy%27s%20Jack%20Ryan">Tom Clancy's Jack Ryan</a>", starring <a href="John%20Krasinski">John Krasinski</a>, as well as "<a href="The%20Equalizer%20%28film%29">The Equalizer</a>" and "<a href="Equalizer%202">Equalizer 2</a>", both starring <a href="Denzel%20Washington">Denzel Washington</a>. Neufeld was given the Lifetime Achievement Award at the 2014 <a href="Israel%20Film%20Festival">Israel Film Festival</a>.
Neufeld died in <a href="Beverly%20Hills%2C%20California">Beverly Hills, California</a>, on January 21, 2022, at the age of 93.
Filmography.
He was a producer in all films unless otherwise noted.
